newsitem.title: USA: Clinton signs legislation to balance budget.
newsitem.headline: Clinton signs legislation to balance budget.

text.p: Amid patriotic music and high-flying rhetoric, President Bill Clinton on Tuesday signed legislation aimed at balancing the U.S. budget and giving Americans $95 billion in tax cuts.
In a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House, Clinton penned his name to a budget bill that resulted from a rare display of unity between political opponents.

"We come here today, Democrats and Republicans, Congress and president, Americans of goodwill from all points of view and all walks of life, to celebrate a true milestone for our nation," Clinton said.

In a show of bipartisanship Clinton, let the top Republican, House Speaker Newt Gingrich, have a lead speaking role. A crowd of 700, including members of Congress and Clinton Cabinet officers, was warmed up by a Marine Corps band that played "God Bless America" and other patriotic tunes.
"This has been a long time coming," Gingrich said. "It has been a difficult process. But in that process we have proven together that the American constitutional system works."
The legislation, approved last week by the Republican-controlled Congress, has the goal of balancing the budget by 2002 while giving Americans their biggest tax cut since 1981.
